title: 103_s245
content:
The "National Commission on Educational Readiness Act" aims to enhance preschool skills development by coordinating efforts of public and private organizations to improve care systems for children and families. The National Commission on Educational Readiness Act establishes a Commission with 11 members appointed by various government officials. The National Commission on Educational Readiness Act establishes a Commission with 11 members appointed by government officials. 3 members will be selected based on expertise in early childhood development, services delivery, teaching, or nonprofit organizations. The Commission will choose a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from its members. The Commission established by the National Commission on Educational Readiness Act consists of 11 members appointed by government officials. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Meetings are held regularly at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of members, with a majority required for a quorum. Members serve 3-year terms, with initial members serving staggered terms of 1, 2, or 3 years. The Commission established by the National Commission on Educational Readiness Act consists of 11 members appointed by government officials. Members serve 3-year terms and may be reappointed. They serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses when engaged in Commission duties. Contracts and arrangements can be entered into as provided in appropriation Acts. The Commission can start its duties under the Act when at least 6 members are appointed. The Commission can start its duties under the Act when at least 6 members are appointed, including the duties outlined in SEC. 4. The Commission is tasked with recommending a national policy for children's formal learning, suggesting changes to Federal laws, promoting State and local initiatives, organizing conferences on readiness to learn, and operating a national clearinghouse for information on school readiness. The Commission is responsible for collaborating with entities involved in readiness to learn issues, developing collaborative arrangements with public agencies and organizations, and providing consultation and technical assistance to State and community entities offering educational services to pregnant women. The Commission provides educational services to pregnant women, infants, toddlers, and preschool children. SEC. 5. REPORTS.

The Commission will submit a comprehensive report to the President and Congress within 1 year of all members being appointed. The report will include findings, recommendations for legislation, and other reports as deemed necessary by the Commission. The Commission can obtain information from Federal agencies, accept gifts, and use the United States mails. They may also have a staff to aid in their activities. The Commission appoints an executive director and necessary personnel to carry out its functions. The staff director is the only employee allowed to be compensated at a rate exceeding the maximum rate for level 15 of the General Schedule. The Commission can request Federal agencies to detail personnel to assist in carrying out its duties under this Act, without interruption or loss of civil service status. SEC. 10. ADVISORY COUNCIL. The Commission shall establish an advisory council composed of representatives of professional and voluntary organizations, scholars, and experts in early childhood development, education, health, and child advocacy. The Council advises the Commission on readiness to learn, strategies under the Act, coordination of activities, and compliance procedures. Recommendations are also made to the Commission. The Council advises the Commission on promoting collaboration, reporting on innovative projects, and supporting ready to learn activities at the state and community levels. The Council advises the Commission on promoting collaboration, reporting on innovative projects, and supporting ready to learn activities at the state and community levels. They also monitor national progress toward the National Education Goal regarding school readiness and develop, exchange, and disseminate information on readiness to learn. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission established under this Act. The Chairman of the Commission can procure temporary services under specific rules, and there is an authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 1994, 1995, and 1996.
